content: I'm wondering about the situation in a multicategory where we have a magma AAA with multiplication μ:(A,A)→A\mu:(A,A)\to Aμ:(A,A)→A together with a binary map ν:(A,A)→X,\nu:(A,A)\to X,ν:(A,A)→X, and we ask about the existence of a factorization ℓ:A→X\ell:A\to Xℓ:A→X of ν\nuν through μ.\mu.μ. If AAA is unital, then such an ℓ\ellℓ must be unique if it exists.

I thought to consider what this looks like in the multicategory of vector spaces over some field k.k.k. Then AAA is a kkk-algebra, not necessarily associative or unital, and if we set X=kX=kX=k then we're asking about the existence of a bilinear form on AAA which factors through AAA's multiplication, so that ⟨a1,a2⟩=ℓ(a1a2)\langle a_1,a_2\rangle= \ell(a_1a_2)⟨a1​,a2​⟩=ℓ(a1​a2​) for some linear form ℓ.\ell.ℓ.

This seems like a natural enough condition, but I'm not able to find occurrences in so-called real life. In general, assuming the multiplication is surjective, then ℓ\ellℓ must be defined by ℓ(a1a2)=⟨a1,a2⟩,\ell(a_1a_2)=\langle a_1,a_2\rangle,ℓ(a1​a2​)=⟨a1​,a2​⟩, so that the condition is equivalent to the inner product being constant on fibers of the product. In particular if the algebra is unital then we can define ℓ(a)=ℓ(1⋅a)=⟨1,a⟩\ell(a)=\ell(1\cdot a)=\langle 1,a\rangleℓ(a)=ℓ(1⋅a)=⟨1,a⟩ and if it's associative then we're asking for an AAA-billinear inner product, since we have ⟨a,bc⟩=L(abc)=⟨ab,c⟩.\langle a,bc\rangle=L(abc)=\langle ab,c\rangle.⟨a,bc⟩=L(abc)=⟨ab,c⟩. I'm currently confused about what happens in the case of C.\mathbf C.C.

Moving away from unital and associative algebras, I thought the idea of invariant inner product on a Lie algebra might produce an example, but in the Lie case my condition reduces instead to ⟨a1,[a2,a3]⟩=⟨a1a2,a3⟩−⟨a2,a1a3⟩\langle a_1,[a_2,a_3]\rangle=\langle a_1a_2,a_3\rangle-\langle a_2,a_1a_3\rangle⟨a1​,[a2​,a3​]⟩=⟨a1​a2​,a3​⟩−⟨a2​,a1​a3​⟩, i.e. it's just the condition that the inner product satisfies the Jacobi identity. And that's not what people mean when they define invariant inner products.

Can anybody think of familiar examples of this behavior occurring, whether in kkk-algebras or in some other practically familiar multicategory? Alternatively, is there some reason why this is a weird structure to think about?

Well, I guess all that happens in the C\mathbf CC case, tautologically, is that you can factor a bilinear form through the multiplication if and only if it's of the form ℓ(xy)\ell(xy)ℓ(xy) for some linear form ℓ:C→R.\ell:\mathbf C\to \mathbf R.ℓ:C→R. Thus there's a 2-dimensional space of bilinear forms on C\mathbf CC that work this way, out of four total dimensions of such forms. And in general, if AAA is an nnn-dimensional algebra with a surjective multiplication, then there's an nnn-dimensional space of bilinear forms that can be made to respect that multiplication out of the n2n^2n2-dimensional space of bilinear forms all in all.

But that still doesn't help me with the question of whether there are important examples of bilinear forms like this!

Kevin Arlin said:

If AAA is unital, then such an ℓ\ellℓ must be unique if it exists.

This seems like a natural enough condition, but I'm not able to find occurrences in so-called real life.

This happens whenever you have a semisimple associative unital algebra over a field kkk - a situation of great importance to old-school algebraists, in part because the algebra of n×nn \times nn×n matrice is an example, and in part because they're completely classified by the Wedderburn-Artin theorem.

I won't always "associative unital" since that's the only case I'm really interested in now, though I will at times digress.
First a few more examples. Over k=Ck = \mathbb{C}k=C the only semisimple algebras are finite direct sums of the n×nn \times nn×n matrix algebras M(n,C)M(n, \mathbb{C})M(n,C).

Over k=Rk = \mathbb{R}k=R the only semisimple algebra are finite direct sums of Mn(R),Mn(C)M_n(\mathbb{R}), M_n(\mathbb{C})Mn​(R),Mn​(C) and Mn(H)M_n(\mathbb{H})Mn​(H), where H\mathbb{H}H is the quaternions.
The Wedderburn-Artin theorem explains and generalizes all this.
Thanks! Is the form you're thinking of on matrix algebras tr(A∗B)\mathrm{tr}(A^*B)tr(A∗B) or something like that?

Wait and see. For any finite-dimensonal algebra (even not necessarily associative or unital!) AAA over a field kkk, there's a god-given bilinear form b:A⊗A→kb: A \otimes A \to kb:A⊗A→k given by

b(x⊗y)=tr(LxLy) b(x \otimes y) = \mathrm{tr}(L_x L_y) b(x⊗y)=tr(Lx​Ly​)
Here Lx:A→AL_x: A \to ALx​:A→A is left multiplication by x∈Ax \in Ax∈A, and tr\mathrm{tr}tr is the usual trace of linear maps from the vector space AAA to itself.

bbb is called the Killing form, and it's symmetric:

b(x⊗y)=b(y⊗x) b(x \otimes y) = b(y \otimes x)b(x⊗y)=b(y⊗x)

The Killing form always gives a linear map ℓ:A→A∗\ell : A \to A^\astℓ:A→A∗ by

ℓ(x)(y)=b(x⊗y) \ell(x) (y) = b(x \otimes y)ℓ(x)(y)=b(x⊗y)

We say an algebra is semisimple if ℓ\ellℓ is an isomorphism. This term is commonly used when AAA is an associative unital algebra - our case of main interest here. It's also widely used for Lie algebras. But we could make this definition for any algebra, not necessarily associative or unital.

Semisimple finite-dimensional algebras that are associative and unital are classified by Wedderburn-Artin, and for these the Killing form b:A⊗A→kb : A \otimes A \to kb:A⊗A→k does what you want: it factors through a linear map ϵ:A→k\epsilon : A \to kϵ:A→k.

What is this map? I'll tell you! The linear map

ι:k→A \iota : k \to Aι:k→A

sending 1∈k1 \in k1∈k to the multiplicative unit 1∈A1 \in A1∈A has as its adjoint a linear map

ι∗:A∗→k∗ \iota^\ast : A^\ast \to k^\astι∗:A∗→k∗
But k∗k^\astk∗ is isomorphic to kkk in a standard way, and since we're assuming AAA is semisimple we have an isomorphism ℓ:A→A∗\ell : A \to A^\astℓ:A→A∗.

Thus ι∗\iota^\astι∗ gives a linear map

ϵ:A→k\epsilon : A \to kϵ:A→k

And this is what we want! It's often called the counit of our semisimple algebra.

In the case when our algebra is a matrix algebra tr(LaLb)\mathrm{tr}(L_a L_b)tr(La​Lb​) proportional but not equal to what you'd call tr(AB)\mathrm{tr}(A B)tr(AB). But note: there's definitely no A∗A^\astA∗ going on here.

The idea here is that matrices happen to act as linear transformations of vectors, but every algebra acts as linear transformations of itself.
If I'm right the Killing form of H\mathbb{H}H over R\mathbb{R}R should be proportional to Re(xy)\mathrm{Re}(xy)Re(xy)...
And the same for O\mathbb{O}O over R\mathbb{R}R ...

Yes, those are correct. Note that these are not positive definite, so they're not inner products, but they are nondegenerate symmetric bilinear forms. The Killing form is always symmetric (fun to check using string diagrams), and its nondegenerate for semisimple algebras (by definition). But the question you raise is: when does the Killing form factor through a map A→kA \to kA→k? And I think it always does when your algebra has a unit.

In the middle of the night I woke up and tried to prove tr(LxLy)=tr(RxRy)\mathrm{tr}(L_x L_y) = \mathrm{tr}(R_x R_y)tr(Lx​Ly​)=tr(Rx​Ry​) and had trouble, though it's pretty easy for commutative algebras, for associative algebras and for Lie algebras.
Then I broke down and used structure constants.

In terms of those the usual "left" Killing form is

bij=cikℓcjℓk b_{i j} = c_{i k}^\ell c_{j \ell}^k bij​=cikℓ​cjℓk​

The "right" Killing form you invented is

bij′=ckiℓcℓjk b'_{ij} = c_{k i}^\ell c^{k}_{\ell j}bij′​=ckiℓ​cℓjk​
I'm using traditional tensor notation here, and the [[Einstein summation convention]], which are the way people drew string diagrams before it was easy to draw string diagrams in papers.

I don't see any reason why these should be equal except in the 3 special cases I mentioned. For commutative algebras we have symmetry:

cikℓ=ckiℓ c_{ik}^\ell = c_{ki}^\ell cikℓ​=ckiℓ​

while for Lie algebras we have antisymmetry:

cikℓ=−ckiℓ c_{ik}^\ell = -c_{ki}^\ell cikℓ​=−ckiℓ​

Either of these make it easy to show bij=bij′b_{ij} = b'_{ij}bij​=bij′​.

Associativity is equivalent to this:

cikℓcℓjm=ciℓmckjℓ c_{i k}^\ell c_{\ell j}^m = c_{i \ell}^m c^\ell_{k j} cikℓ​cℓjm​=ciℓm​ckjℓ​
Hmm, now I'm not even succeeding in showing the left and right Killing forms agree for associative algebras! I've got a page of computations here, but I'm not getting it!

I may be getting tangled up somehow.

But for now, I take back my claim: I'm reduced to saying the left and right Killing forms agree for algebras with a commutative product or with an anticommutative product.
